revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Year nav topic5|1601|literature}}
This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1601'''.
==Events== *[[January 6]] – The [[Children of the Chapel]] give their first theatrical performance at the English Court since 1584. This year they stage the first production of [[Ben Jonson]]'s ''[[The Poetaster]]''. *[[January 21]] – [[Tirso de Molina]] enters the monastery of San Antolín at Guadalajara, Spain. *[[February 7]] – The [[Lord Chamberlain's Men]] stage a performance of [[Shakespeare]]'s ''[[Richard II (play)|Richard II]]'' at the [[Globe Theatre]] in London. The performance is specially commissioned (at a 40-shilling bonus) by the plotters in the [[Robert Devereux, 2nd Earl of Essex|Earl of Essex]]'s rebellion of the following day. The plotters hope that the play, depicting the overthrow of a reigning monarch, will influence the public mood in their favour. The plot fails. *[[February 17]] – Actor [[Augustine Phillips]], a member of the Lord Chamberlain's Men, is deposed by the [[Privy Council of England]]. *Spring – Probable latest date for first performance of Shakespeare's ''[[Hamlet]]''.<ref>{{cite book|editor=Edwards, Phillip|year=1985|title=Hamlet, Prince of Denmark|series=New Cambridge Shakespeare|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=0-521-29366-9|page=8|quote=Any dating of Hamlet must be tentative.}} Scholars date its writing as between 1599 and 1601.</ref> The play is presented by the [[Lord Chamberlain's Men]] at the [[Globe Theatre]] in London with [[Richard Burbage]] playing [[Prince Hamlet]] and (according to theatrical tradition) the dramatist playing the [[Ghost (Hamlet)|Ghost]]. *July – [[Lancelot Andrewes]] becomes Dean of Westminster. *[[Thomas Overbury]] meets [[Robert Carr, 1st Earl of Somerset]], and they become firm friends. *[[Tommaso Campanella]], imprisoned in Italy for revolutionary plotting, is judged insane and spared the death penalty. He is sentenced to life imprisonment, and begins to write ''[[The City of the Sun]]''. *[[Philemon Holland]] publishes his translation of the [[Natural History (Pliny)|''Natural History'']] of [[Pliny the Elder]]. When he composes ''[[Othello]]'' in the next year of so, Shakespeare exploits the book for references, including the "Anthropophagi" and the "Pontic Sea."
==New books== ===Prose=== *[[Nicolas Barnaud]] – ''De Occulta philosophia'' *[[Carolus Clusius]] – ''Rariarum plantarum historia'' *[[Antonio de Herrera y Tordesillas]] – ''Historia general de los hechos de los Castellanos'', volume 1 *[[Nicholas Hill (scientist)|Nicholas Hill]] – ''Philosophia epicurea'' *[[Philemon Holland]] – ''The Historie of the World'', a translation of [[Pliny the Elder|Pliny]]'s ''[[Natural History (Pliny)|Natural History]]'' *[[Thomas Middleton]] – ''The Penniless Parliament of Threadbare Poets'' *[[Mavro Orbin]] – ''The Realm of the Slavs'' *[[Achilles Tatius]] – ''[[Leucippe and Clitophon|The Adventures of Leucippe and Cleitophon]]'' (first printed edition of original Greek text, published [[Heidelberg]]) *[[Brás Viegas]] – ''Commentarii exegetici in Apocalypsim''
===Drama=== *Anonymous **(Sebastian Westcote?) – ''The Contention Between Liberality and Prodigality'' **''[[Parnassus plays|The Return from Parnassus]]'' *[[Thomas Dekker (writer)|Thomas Dekker]] – ''[[Satiromastix]]'' and ''[[Blurt, Master Constable|Blurt, Master Constable, or The Spaniards Night-Walke]]'' (with [[Thomas Middleton]]?) *[[Ben Jonson]] – ''[[The Poetaster]]'' performed; ''[[Cynthia's Revels]]'' published *[[John Lyly]] – ''[[Love's Metamorphosis]]'' published *[[John Marston (poet)|John Marston]] – ''[[What You Will]]'' *[[Anthony Munday]] – [[The Downfall and The Death of Robert Earl of Huntington|''The Downfall'' and ''The Death of Robert Earl of Huntington'']] published together *[[William Percy (writer)|William Percy]] – ''Arabia sitiens, or, A Dreame of a Drye Yeare: a Tragaecomodye'' *[[William Shakespeare]] – ''[[Twelfth Night]], or What You Will''; ''[[Hamlet]]'' (possible first performance) *[[Robert Yarington]] – ''Two Lamentable Tragedies'' published
===Poetry=== *[[Robert Chester (poet)|Robert Chester]] – ''Love's Martyr''. The volume also contains fourteen poems by other hands, including: **[[William Shakespeare]] – ''[[The Phoenix and the Turtle]]'' *[[Gervase Markham]] – ''Mary Magdalene's Tears'' *[[John Weever]] – ''The Mirror of Martyrs, or The Life and Death of Sir John Oldcastle'' *[[Bento Teixeira]] – ''Prosopopeia''
==Births== *[[January 8]] – [[Baltasar Gracián]], Spanish Jesuit writer (died [[1658 in literature|1658]]) *[[March 7]] – [[Johann Michael Moscherosch]], German satirist (died [[1669 in literature|1669]]) *[[June 5]] – [[John Trapp]], English Biblical commentator (died [[1669 in literature|1669]]) *[[July 17]] – [[Emmanuel Maignan]], French theologian (died [[1676 in literature|1676]]) *[[August 22]] – [[Georges de Scudéry]], French novelist, dramatist and poet (died [[1667 in literature|1667]]) *''Probable year of birth'' – [[François Tristan l'Hermite]], French dramatist (died [[1655 in literature|1655]])
==Deaths== *[[January 11]] – [[Scipione Ammirato]], Italian historian (born [[1531 in literature|1531]]) *[[March 13]] – [[Henry Cuffe]], English philosophical writer and politician (executed, born [[1563 in literature|1563]]) *[[April 10]] – [[Mark Alexander Boyd]], Scottish poet (born [[1562 in literature|1562]]) *[[August 19]] – [[William Lambarde]], English antiquary and lawyer (born [[1536 in literature|1536]]) *[[August 31]] – [[Gian Vincenzo Pinelli]], Italian humanist and book collector (born [[1535 in literature|1535]]) *[[September 7]] – [[John Shakespeare]], English glover and father of [[William Shakespeare]] (born c. 1530) *[[November 8]] – [[John Hooker (English constitutionalist)|John Hooker]], English constitutionalist (born c. 1527) *''Approximate year of death'' – [[Thomas Nashe]], [[English poetry|English]] pamphleteer, poet and satirist (born [[1567 in poetry|1567]])
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:1601 In Literature}} [[Category:1601 books| ]] [[Category:Years in literature]] [[Category:Years of the 17th century in literature]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = 90 Minutes in Heaven | image = 90 Minutes in Heaven (film) poster.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | film name = <!--(for non-English films: film's name in its native language)--> | director = [[Michael Polish]] |producers = {{unbulleted list|[[Randall Emmett]]|Dawn Parouse|[[George Furla]]|Rick Jackson|Harrison Powell|Timothy C. Sullivan}} | screenplay = Michael Polish | based on = {{based on|''[[90 Minutes in Heaven]]''|Don Piper and [[Cecil Murphey]]}} | starring = {{unbulleted list|[[Hayden Christensen]]|[[Kate Bosworth]]|[[Dwight Yoakam]]|[[Michael W. Smith]]|Michael Harding}} | narrator = <!-- or: |narrators = --> | music = | cinematography = [[M. David Mullen]] | editing = Cary Gries | production companies = {{unbulleted list|[[Emmett/Furla/Oasis Films|Emmett/Furla Films]]|[[Family Christian Stores|Family Christian Entertainment]]|Giving Films}} | distributor = [[Samuel Goldwyn Films]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Busch |first=Anita |url=http://deadline.com/2015/07/90-minutes-in-heaven-trailer-hayden-christensen-kate-bosworth-1201472053/ |title=Trailer: Hayden Christensen’s ’90 Minutes In Heaven’ |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=2015-07-08 |accessdate=2015-08-06}}</ref> | released = {{Film date|2015|09|11}} | runtime = 121 minutes<ref>{{cite web|author=EVO Entertainment |url=http://www.evo-entertainment.com/movie/90-minutes-in-heaven/ |title=90 Minutes In Heaven |website=EVO Entertainment |accessdate=2015-09-01}}</ref> | country = United States
| budget = $5 million<ref>{{cite web|last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://deadline.com/2015/01/family-christian-retail-chain-forms-film-shingle-with-90-minutes-in-heaven-1201343935/ |title=Family Christian Retail Chain To Make ’90 Minutes In Heaven’ Movie |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=2015-01-07 |accessdate=2015-09-01}}</ref> | gross = $4.8 million<ref name="BOM">{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=90minutesinheaven.htm |title=90 Minutes in Heaven (2015) |website=Box Office Mojo |accessdate=October 12, 2015}}</ref> }} '''''90 Minutes in Heaven''''' is a 2015 [[Christian film industry|Christian]] [[drama film]] directed by [[Michael Polish]] and starring [[Hayden Christensen]], [[Kate Bosworth]], [[Dwight Yoakam]], [[Michael W. Smith]], and Michael Harding. It is based on the bestselling [[90 Minutes in Heaven|novel by the same name]].<ref name="Christian Today 3"/><ref name="The Gospel Herald">{{cite news|last1=Schuster|first1=Shawn|title='90 Minutes in Heaven' Film Based on Best-Selling Book Expected to Release This Fall|url=http://www.gospelherald.com/articles/54717/20150312/90-minutes-in-heaven-film-starring-michael-w-smith-expected-to-release-this-fall.htm|accessdate=May 25, 2015|work=[[Review and Herald Publishing Association|The Gospel Herald]]|date=March 12, 2015}}</ref><ref name="The Global Dispatch 2"/> It is the first film by Giving Films, a sister company to retail chain [[Family Christian Stores]],<ref name="Baptist Standard 1">{{cite news|last1=Allen|first1=Bob|title='90 Minutes in Heaven' headed to big screen|url=https://www.baptiststandard.com/news/faith-culture/17617-90-minutes-in-heaven-headed-to-big-screen|accessdate=May 25, 2015|work=The Baptist Standard|date=March 27, 2015}}</ref> and though the company announced plans to donate all profits from the film to charitable organizations, the poorly reviewed film showed a loss at the box office.<ref name="Christian Today 1">{{cite web|url=http://www.christiantoday.com/article/90.minutes.in.heaven.wraps.up.filming.in.atlanta/49965.htm|title='90 Minutes in Heaven' wraps up filming in Atlanta |author=Yapching, Mark |date= March 16, 2015|website=[[Christian Today]]|accessdate=21 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charismanews.com/us/48825-watch-90-minutes-in-heaven-film-tells-riveting-story-of-life-after-death|title=WATCH: '90 Minutes in Heaven' Film Tells Riveting Story of Life After Death|agency=[[Religion News Service]]|format=text and video|work=[[Charisma (magazine)|Charisma Magazine]]|accessdate=21 May 2015}}</ref><ref name="Daily Mail 1">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2965806/Hayden-Christensen-unrecognizable-red-hair-mustache-play-car-crash-survivor-90-Minutes-Heaven.html|author=Carballo, Charlie |date=February 23, 2015 |title=Hayden Christensen is unrecognizable in 90 Minutes To Heaven with red hair|work=[[Daily Mail]]|accessdate=21 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/01/family-christian-retail-chain-forms-film-shingle-with-90-minutes-in-heaven-1201343935/|title=Family Christian Retail Chain Forms Film Shingle With ' ''90 Minutes In Heaven'' '|date=January 7, 2015|author=Fleming Jr., Mike|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=May 18, 2015}}</ref>
==Premise== Don Piper is involved in a horrific car crash, pronounced dead at the scene and covered by a tarp. Ninety minutes later, having been brought to a hospital, he returns to life and claims to have seen Heaven and visited with deceased relatives while there.
==Cast== * [[Hayden Christensen]] as Don Piper * [[Kate Bosworth]] as Eva Piper * [[Dwight Yoakam]] as Cecil Beaumont * [[Fred Thompson]] as Jay B. Perkins * [[Michael W. Smith]] as Cliff McArdle * Michael Harding as Dick Onarecker * [[Rhoda Griffis]] as Principal Mary Nell * [[Marshall Bell]] as Dr. Greider
==Production== The project was shot in [[Atlanta]], Georgia,<ref name="Neighbor Newspapers">{{cite news|last1=staff|title=‘90 Minutes in Heaven’ filmed in Buckhead|url=http://neighbornewspapers.com/bookmark/26505419--90-Minutes-in-Heaven-filmed-in-Buckhead|accessdate=May 25, 2015|work=[[The Marietta Daily Journal]]|date=March 5, 2015}}</ref> and the shooting finished in March 2015.<ref name="Christian Today 1"/><ref>{{cite web|author=Law, Jeannie |date=March 12, 2015 |url=http://www.breathecast.com/articles/don-pipers-90-minutes-in-heaven-movie-ends-production-schedules-release-date-michael-w-smith-stars-in-leading-role-video-25780/|title=Don Piper's '90 Minutes In Heaven' Movie Ends Production: Kate Bosworth, Michael W. Smith & More Appear in Leading Roles|format=text and video| work=Breathecast|accessdate=22 May 2015}}</ref><ref name="Religion News Service">{{cite news|last1=Conrad|first1=Michael|title=‘90 MINUTES IN HEAVEN’ Wraps Atlanta Filming|url=http://pressreleases.religionnews.com/2015/03/12/90-minutes-heaven-wraps-atlanta-filming/|accessdate=May 23, 2015|website=[[Religion News Service]]|date=March 12, 2015}}</ref> Since its publication, [[Don Piper]]'s book was twice on the [[New York Times Best Seller]] list, was listed as a ''[[USA Today]]'' best-seller,<ref name=cr>{{cite web|url=http://www.christianretailing.com/index.php/newsletter/latest/26973-pipers-90-minutes-in-heaven-back-on-new-york-times-best-seller-list|title=Piper’s ‘90 Minutes in Heaven’ back on ‘New York Times’ best-seller list|work=Christian Retailing|date=25 April 2014}}</ref> and has sold 7 million copies in 46 languages.<ref name="Christian Film Database">{{cite web|last1=staff|title=90 Minutes in Heaven|url=http://www.christianfilmdatabase.com/review/90-minutes-heaven/|website=[[Christian Film Database]]|accessdate=May 23, 2015}}</ref> The producers chose to stay as true to the book which inspired the film as possible:<ref name="Christian Today 2"/>{{blockquote|{{sic}}"I think a lot of people read books, especially true stories, and then the movie is not even close to the real story and they make up things. I told Don that I thought the story stood for itself and my commitment to him was that it would be true to the book, and be true period." - Rick Jackson<ref name="Christian Today 2"/>}} Actress Kate Bosworth stated she "was amazed how Piper's story affects so many people" and that she felt blessed "to be a part of the movie's cast."<ref name="Christian Today 2">{{cite news|last1=Ong|first1=Czarina|title=90 Minutes in Heaven producer explains why they stayed faithful to Don Piper's book|url=http://www.christiantoday.com/article/90.minutes.in.heaven.producer.explains.why.they.stayed.faithful.to.don.pipers.book/54526.htm|accessdate=May 23, 2015|website=[[Christian Today]]|date=May 23, 2015}}</ref> Filming began in January 2015,<ref name="Christian Today 3">{{cite news|last1=Lopez-Mitjavile|first1=Diana Lyn|title=Pastor's near-death experience made into movie, starring Kate Bosworth, Hayden Christensen|url=http://www.christiantoday.com.au/article/pastors.near.death.experience.made.into.movie.starring.kate.bosworth.hayden.christensen/19292.htm|accessdate=May 25, 2015|website=[[Christian Today]]|date=January 12, 2015}}</ref><ref name="The Global Dispatch 2">{{cite news|last1=Jones|first1=Brandon|title=’90 Minutes In Heaven’ Goes Into Production, New Site Up With Kate Bosworth, Hayden Christenson|url=http://www.theglobaldispatch.com/90-minutes-in-heaven-goes-into-production-new-site-up-with-kate-bosworth-hayden-christenson-75720/|accessdate=May 25, 2015|work=The Global Dispatch|date=January 31, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Christian Post 1">{{cite news|last1=Koonse|first1=Emma|title=Family Christian Entertainment 'To Be the Disney' of Faith-Based Films As '90 Minutes In Heaven' Enters Production|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/family-christian-entertainment-to-be-the-disney-of-faith-based-films-as-90-minutes-in-heaven-enters-production-132630/|accessdate=May 25, 2015|work=[[The Christian Post]]|date=January 15, 2015}}</ref> and by March 8, 2015, filming had wrapped and the project went into post-production.<ref name="Global Dispatch 1">{{cite news|last1=staff|title=’90 Minutes In Heaven’ Wraps, Still Set For 2015 Release|url=http://www.theglobaldispatch.com/90-minutes-in-heaven-wraps-still-set-for-2015-release-88855/|accessdate=May 25, 2015|work=The Global Dispatch|date=March 14, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Daily Mail 2">{{cite news|last1=White|first1=Chelsea|title='In heaven!' Kate Bosworth and her director husband Michael Polish share a kiss to celebrate wrapping their new film|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2985825/Kate-Bosworth-director-husband-Michael-Polish-share-kiss-celebrate-wrapping-new-film.html|accessdate=May 25, 2015|work=[[Daily Mail]]|date=March 8, 2015}}</ref>
==Release== ===Home media===
''90 Minutes in Heaven'' was released on DVD and Blu-ray on December 1, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dvdsreleasedates.com/movies/7691/90-minutes-in-heaven |title=90 Minutes in Heaven DVD and Blu-ray |website=dvdsreleasedates.com |accessdate=2015-12-16}}</ref>
==Reception== ''90 Minutes in Heaven'' has received negative reviews from critics. On [[Rotten Tomatoes]] the film holds a rating of 24%, based on 21 reviews, with an average rating of 4.4/10.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/90_minutes_in_heaven/|title=90 Minutes in Heaven |website=Rotten Tomatoes |accessdate=January 30, 2016}}</ref> [[Metacritic]] gives the film a score of 28 out of 100, based on reviews from 9 critics, indicating "generally unfavorable reviews".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/90-minutes-in-heaven |title=90 Minutes in Heaven reviews |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=September 17, 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://90minutesinheaventhemovie.com/}} * {{IMDb title|4337690|90 Minutes in Heaven}}
{{Michael Polish}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:90 Minutes in Heaven (film)}} [[Category:2015 films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Films about death]] [[Category:Films based on biographies]] [[Category:Films set in 1989]] [[Category:Films shot in Atlanta]] [[Category:Films set in heaven]] [[Category:American independent films]] [[Category:Near-death experiences]] [[Category:Emmett/Furla/Oasis Films films]]

revision.comment: [[Wikipedia:OABOT|Open access bot]]: add pmc identifier to citation with #oabot.
revision.text:
{{wikisource|A Frank Statement}} [[File:A Frank Statement.png|thumb|''A Frank Statement to Cigarette Smokers'']] '''''A Frank Statement to Cigarette Smokers''''' was a historic first [[Tobacco advertising|advertisement]] in a campaign run by major American [[tobacco]] [[Tobacco industry|companies]] on January 4, 1954, to create doubt by disputing recent scientific studies linking smoking [[cigarettes]] to [[lung cancer]] and other dangerous [[Health effects of tobacco|health effects]].<ref name=":32">{{Cite web|url=http://www.tobacco.org/Documents/dd/ddfrankstatement.html|title=Daily Doc: The "Frank Statement" of 1954|last=|first=|date=2017-11-07|website=www.tobacco.org|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-11-07}}</ref>
Reaching an estimated 43 million people through more than 400 newspapers throughout the United States, ''A Frank Statement to Cigarette Smokers'' and subsequent advertisements were designed by public relations firm [[Hill & Knowlton]] to [[Social engineering (political science)|socially engineer]] the public's perceptions of tobacco and to instill doubt about scientific research linking disease and smoking.<ref name=":32"/><ref name=":02">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/900540359|title=Up in smoke : from legislation to litigation in tobacco politics|last=Martha|first=Derthick|publisher=CQ Press|year=|isbn=1452202230|edition=Third|location=Washington, D.C.|pages=33–41|oclc=900540359}}</ref> As a result of ''A Frank Statement'' and tobacco advertisements that still exist today, the tobacco industry continues to expand its markets by avoiding health concerns and portraying its products in a positive light.<ref name=":9">{{Cite book|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK236761/|title=TOBACCO ADVERTISING AND PROMOTION|last=Youths|first=Institute of Medicine (US) Committee on Preventing Nicotine Addiction in Children and|last2=Lynch|first2=Barbara S.|last3=Bonnie|first3=Richard J.|date=1994|publisher=National Academies Press (US)|language=en}}</ref>
==Historical context==
Reports of a link between tobacco and lung cancer emerged as early as 1912, but until the 1950s, the evidence was circumstantial since smoking was so pervasive in society.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Thun|first=Michael J|date=2005|title=When truth is unwelcome : the first reports on smoking and lung cancer : Public Health Classics|url=http://www.who.int/iris/handle/10665/73130}}</ref>
In 1950, hoping to find the cause of the significant surge in lung cancer incidence in the US and England, [[Richard Doll|Dr. Richard Doll]] and [[Austin Bradford Hill|Professor Bradford Hill]] conducted a [[case-control study]] in which [[lung cancer]], other cancer, and non-cancer patients from twenty London-area hospitals were interviewed about their smoking habits. The study, published in the ''[[The BMJ|British Medical Journal]]'', found that the lung cancer patients were more likely to be heavier smokers than the other cancer and non-cancer control patients.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Doll|first=Richard|last2=Hill|first2=A. Bradford|date=1950-09-30|title=Smoking and Carcinoma of the Lung|journal=British Medical Journal|volume=2|issue=4682|pages=739–748|issn=0007-1447|pmc=2038856|pmid=14772469|doi=10.1136/bmj.2.4682.739}}</ref> These results revealed to the medical community that a link between smoking and lung cancer may exist. Smoking was so prevalent that before these results were published, the increase in lung cancer incidence was attributed to the growing presence of automobiles, roads, and factories in cities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sphweb.bumc.bu.edu/otlt/mph-modules/ep/ep713_history/EP713_History8.html|title=Epidemiology of Chronic Diseases|last=LaMorte|first=Wayne W.|date=October 18, 2017|website=sphweb.bumc.bu.edu|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-11-07}}</ref> [[File:Wynder and Graham Figure 3.png|thumb|Wynder and Graham's study found that lung cancer patients were more likely to be heavier smokers than the other cancer and non-cancer control patients.]] In 1950, [[Ernst Wynder|Dr. Ernst Wynder]] and [[Evarts Ambrose Graham]] published a study in the [[JAMA (journal)|Journal of the American Medical Association]] in which they interviewed 684 people with proven cases of lung cancer about their smoking habits. The study found that heavy and sustained usage of tobacco, especially in the form of cigarettes, increased the likelihood of developing of lung cancer.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Wynder|first=Ernest L.|last2=Graham|first2=Evarts A.|date=1985-05-24|title=Tobacco Smoking as a Possible Etiologic Factor in Bronchiogenic Carcinoma: A Study of Six Hundred and Eighty-Four Proved Cases|url=https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/398680|journal=JAMA|volume=253|issue=20|pages=2986–2994|doi=10.1001/jama.1985.03350440064033|issn=0098-7484|pmc=2623809}}</ref> In 1952, to study the biological likelihood of cancer being linked to smoking, [[Ernst Wynder|Wynder]] published an animal study in the US journal ''[[Cancer Research (journal)|Cancer Research]]'' that found that tobacco tar was [[carcinogen]]ic when applied to the skin of mice.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/795182557|title=Drugs-- without the hot air : minimising the harms of legal and illegal drugs|last=Nutt|first=David|date=2012|publisher=UIT|year=|isbn=1906860165|location=Cambridge, England|pages=201–202|oclc=795182557}}</ref>
The December 1952 issue of ''[[Reader's Digest]]'' featured an article, titled ''Cancer by the Carton,'' that discussed these recent studies on the link between smoking and lung cancer. The article presented to the public the studies' conclusion that tobacco causes lung cancer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/bcm92f00/pdf|title=Cancer by the Carton|last=Norr|first=Roy|date=December 1952|website=legacy.library.ucsf.edu|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-11-07}}</ref> As a result, the article provoked a health scare, which resulted in a small drop in consumption, and a fall in stock prices.<ref name=":02"/>
In 1954, Doll and Hill published another article in the ''British Medical Journal'' releasing the results of the [[British Doctors Study]],<nowiki/>which revealed a significant pattern of increased death from lung cancer as the amount of tobacco smoked increased.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Doll|first=Richard|last2=Hill|first2=A. Bradford|date=1954-06-26|title=The Mortality of Doctors in Relation to Their Smoking Habits|journal=British Medical Journal|volume=1|issue=4877|pages=1451–1455|issn=0007-1447|pmc=2085438|pmid=13160495|doi=10.1136/bmj.1.4877.1451}}</ref>
In the early 1950s, which were the immediate post-war years and the beginning of the [[Atomic Age|nuclear age]], science was very highly regarded by the public, so the accumulating scientific evidence linking tobacco to lung cancer posed a major threat to the tobacco companies' public image.<ref name=":42">{{Cite journal|last=Brandt|first=Allan M.|date=January 2012|title=Inventing Conflicts of Interest: A History of Tobacco Industry Tactics|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=102|issue=1|pages=63–71|doi=10.2105/AJPH.2011.300292|issn=0090-0036|pmc=3490543|pmid=22095331}}</ref>
== Social engineering == With mounting evidence of a link between smoking tobacco and lung cancer, tobacco companies faced a dilemma of whether to admit to or deny the health risks of smoking. In order to preserve their industry, the tobacco companies opted to completely deny health risks. Instead, the tobacco companies crafted a strategy that, through creative advertising and marketing, would manipulate the cultural context surrounding their product from one that regarded the product unfavorably to one that held the product in high esteem. This strategy is known as [[Social engineering (security)|social engineering]].<ref name=":42"/>
On December 15, 1953, led by Paul Hahn, the head of [[American Tobacco Company|American Tobacco]], the six major tobacco companies ([[American Tobacco Company|American Tobacco Co.]], [[R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company|R. J. Reynolds]], [[Philip Morris International|Philip Morris]], [[Benson & Hedges]], [[U.S. Tobacco Company|U.S. Tobacco Co.]], and Brown & Williamson) met with public relations company [[Hill & Knowlton]] in New York City to create an advertisement that would assuage the public's fears and create a false sense of security in order to regain the public's confidence in the tobacco industry.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-09-18/magazine/tm-40179_1_tobacco-industry|title=Tobacco's Pr Campaign : The Cigarette Papers|last=Goodman|first=Michael J.|date=1994-09-18|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-11-07|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref> Hill and Knowlton's president, [[John W. Hill]], realized that simply denying the health risks would not be enough to convince the public. Instead, a more effective method would be to create a major scientific controversy in which the scientifically established link between smoking tobacco and lung cancer would appear not to be conclusively known.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tobaccotactics.org/index.php?title=Hill_%26_Knowlton|title=Hill & Knowlton|last=University of Bath|first=|date=October 17, 2012|website=www.TobaccoTactics.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The tobacco companies fought against the emerging science by producing their own science, which suggested that existing science was incomplete and that the industry was not motivated by self-interest.<ref name=":42"/> With the creation of the [[Tobacco Institute|Tobacco Industry Research Committee]], headed by accomplished scientist [[C. C. Little|C.C. Little]], the tobacco companies manufactured doubt and turned scientific findings into a topic of debate. The recruitment of credentialed scientists like Little who were skeptics was a crucial aspect of the tobacco companies' social engineering plan to establish credibility against [[Tobacco control|anti-smoking reports]]. By amplifying the voices of a few skeptical scientists, the industry created an illusion that the larger scientific community had not reached a conclusive agreement on the link between smoking and cancer.<ref name=":42"/>
Internal documents released through [[whistleblower]]s and [[Lawsuit|litigation]], such as the [[Tobacco Master Settlement Agreement]], reveal that while advertisements like ''A Frank Statement'' made tobacco companies appear to be responsible and concerned for the health of their consumers, in reality, they were deceiving the public into believing that smoking did not have health risks. The whole project was aimed at protecting the tobacco companies' images of glamour and all-American individualism at the cost of the public's health.<ref name=":1">Bates, Clive, and Andy Rowell. "[http://www.who.int/tobacco/media/en/TobaccoExplained.pdf Tobacco Explained]" (PDF). World Health Organization.</ref>
==Claims== ''A Frank Statement to Cigarette Smokers'' claims: # That medical research of recent years indicates many possible causes of lung cancer. # That there is no agreement among the authorities regarding what the cause is. # That there is no proof that cigarette smoking is one of the causes. # That statistics purporting to link cigarette smoking with the disease could apply with equal force to any one of many other aspects of modern life. Indeed, the validity of the statistics themselves is questioned by numerous scientists.<ref name=":32" /> The claims made in ''A Frank Statement'' were largely false as: # Recent medical research had indicated that while lung cancer does have many possible causes, smoking is by far the leading cause in many different types of cancer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM195204032461405|title=Some Practical Aspects of Cancer Prevention|last=Wynder|first=Ernest L.|date=April 3, 1952|website=The New England Journal of Medicine|language=EN|doi=10.1056/nejm195204032461405|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-11-12}}</ref> # Most scientists, except for skeptics hired by the tobacco companies, agreed that cigarette smoking is linked to lung cancer incidence.<ref name=":1" /> # Multiple studies have shown a clear link between cigarette smoking and lung cancer.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /><ref name=":7" /> # The studies linking cigarette smoking to lung cancer controlled for the "many other aspects of modern life" to show that cigarette smoking is the main cause.<ref name=":6" /> Many of the "numerous scientists" who questioned the validity of the statistics were under the payroll of the tobacco companies.<ref name=":32" /><ref name=":42" />
==Promises== The advertisement also made several promises on behalf of the tobacco industry which were later disputed by the scientific community. In ''A Frank Statement,'' the tobacco companies stated that they believed that their products were safe; however, in a 2002 assessment of the promises made by the advertisement, it was concluded that some tobacco industry scientists believed that there was a [[Causality|causal relationship]] between tobacco and cancer.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Cummings|first=K. M.|last2=Morley|first2=C. P.|last3=Hyland|first3=A.|date=March 2002|title=Failed promises of the cigarette industry and its effect on consumer misperceptions about the health risks of smoking|journal=Tobacco Control|volume=11 Suppl 1|pages=I110–117|doi=10.1136/tc.11.suppl_1.i110|issn=0964-4563|pmc=1766060|pmid=11893821}}</ref> Research was undertaken to find a safer cigarette, but tobacco companies realized that they could not produce a safer cigarette because doing so would mean admitting that current cigarettes were not safe.<ref name=":2" /> Thus, the industry responded to the growing public concern by marketing their cigarettes as having [[Cigarette filter|filters]], milder smoke, and lower tar and [[Nicotine dependence|nicotine]] content; however, they did not acknowledge a causal link with cancer until 1999.<ref name=":2" />
''A Frank Statement'' also pledged "aid and assistance to the research effort into all phases of tobacco use and health," and announced the establishment of the [[Tobacco Institute|Tobacco Industry Research Committee]] (TIRC) to work towards that goal.<ref name=":32" /> Much of the TIRC funded research was not directly connected to smoking as it focused mainly on cancer basics, such as [[immunology]], [[genetics]], [[cell biology]], [[pharmacology]], and [[virology]], rather than cancer's connection to smoking.<ref name=":42" /> Neither the TIRC nor its successor, the Council for Tobacco Research, ever acknowledged a proven link between smoking and serious and/or life-threatening illness. When research did find a link between smoking and cancer, however, the findings were rarely reported to the public.<ref name=":2" /> Despite the irrelevance of much of the TIRC funded research to the health effects of smoking, the tobacco industry continued to publicize its funding of the TIRC to reassure the public.<ref name=":2" /> In reality, the TIRC was created as a public relations measure for the purposes of discrediting independent science and portraying the tobacco companies as transparent and concerned for the well-being of their customers.<ref name=":42" />
Finally, the advertisement promised that the tobacco companies "always have and always will cooperate closely with those whose task it is to safeguard the public health."<ref name=":32" /> According to Cummings, Morley, and Hyland, "there is abundant evidence that the tobacco industry went to great lengths to undermine tobacco control efforts of the public health community."<ref name=":2" /> An example of this is a memo from the vice-president of the [[Tobacco Institute]] in which the industry's strategy was described as "creating doubt about the health charge without actually denying it", and "advocating the public's right to smoke, without actually urging them to take up the practice."<ref name=":2" /> By proclaiming that the health risks were not conclusively linked to smoking, the tobacco companies manipulated the situation to place all liability on the consumer rather than on themselves.<ref name=":42" />
== Impact on the public == Although the tobacco industry claims that their advertising is only used to convince current smokers to switch between brands and that it does not increase total cigarette consumption, research into the effects of advertising shows that it plays an essential role in projecting positive connotations of smoking cigarettes onto potential new smokers.<ref name=":1" /> From 1954, when Hill & Knowlton first started working with the tobacco industry, to 1961, the number of cigarettes sold annually rose from 369 billion to 488 billion, and the annual per capita consumption rose from 3344 to 4025 cigarettes.<ref name=":42" />
The [[Tobacco advertising|first cigarette advertisements]] claimed that smoking cigarettes had a variety of health benefits, such as prolonged youth, thinness, and attractiveness.<ref name=":1" /> However, as more research revealed the deceptiveness of these claims, tobacco companies began to use advertisements, like ''A Frank Statement,'' to deny that their products caused cancer. Claiming that advertisement bans would infringe on "commercial [[Freedom of speech|free speech]]," the tobacco industry has continually fought against them; however, the industry has never responded to criticism that much of its advertising, like the claims made in ''A Frank Statement,'' is deceptive.<ref name=":1" /> As a result, the tobacco industry's manipulation of science as a public relations tactic is still used today in debates on a wide variety of subjects including [[global warming]], [[Genetically modified organism|food]], and [[Pharmaceutical drug|pharmaceuticals]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brownell|first=Kelly D.|last2=Warner|first2=Kenneth E.|date=March 2009|title=The perils of ignoring history: Big Tobacco played dirty and millions died. How similar is Big Food?|journal=The Milbank Quarterly|volume=87|issue=1|pages=259–294|doi=10.1111/j.1468-0009.2009.00555.x|issn=1468-0009|pmc=2879177|pmid=19298423}}</ref>
== Modern-day examples == Today, tobacco companies continue to aggressively advertise cigarettes. As cigarette consumption has declined in the United States, tobacco companies have greatly increased their advertising expenditure. In 1991, the industry spent $4.6 billion on advertising and promoting cigarette consumption,<ref name=":9" /> and in 2015, tobacco companies spent $8.9 billion on advertising just in the United States.<ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/tobacco/data_statistics/fact_sheets/tobacco_industry/marketing/index.htm|title=CDC - Fact Sheet - Tobacco Industry Marketing - Smoking & Tobacco Use|last=Health|first=CDC's Office on Smoking and|date=2017-11-16|website=Smoking and Tobacco Use|language=en-us|access-date=2017-12-06}}</ref> Tobacco companies continue to use this money to fund social engineering techniques, such as campaigns featuring themes of social desirability and specific cultural references, to target women, children, and specific racial/ethnic communities.<ref name=":8" /> For example, to make cigarettes appealing to African American communities, the industry has implemented campaigns that use urban culture and language while sponsoring Chinese and Vietnamese New Year festivals to target Asian Americans.<ref name=":8" />
With declining levels of smoking in the West due to [[List of smoking bans|smoking bans]] and increased education on the health risks of smoking, tobacco companies have also expanded their market into [[Developing country|developing countries]] to fulfill the industry's ever-present need for new smokers and more money. Using many of the same advertising techniques of glamour, sex, and independence, the industry has begun to target women and children in Eastern Europe, Asia, Latin America, and Africa, where government bans and health education may not be as prevalent.<ref name=":1" />
==See also== * [[Tobacco industry]] * [[Tobacco advertising]] * [[Social engineering (political science)|Social engineering]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.sourcewatch.org/index.php?title=The_Frank_Statement The Frank Statement] at [[SourceWatch]]

{{Infobox artwork/wikidata|suppressfields=owner}} '''''A Vase of Flowers''''' is a 1716 floral painting by the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] painter [[Margaretha Haverman]]. It is in the collection of the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]].<ref name=RKD>{{Cite web|url=https://rkd.nl/explore/images/197003 |title=Stilleven van een boeket bloemen in een terracotta vaas en vruchten in een nis, 1716 gedateerd|publisher=[[RKD]]}}</ref>
==Acquisition== This work was acquired as part of the initial purchase in 1871 of 174 paintings bought in Europe by [[William Tilden Blodgett]], one of the museum's initial donors and trustees. It is signed and dated ''Margareta Haverman fecit / A 1716''.<ref name=Liedtke>[https://books.google.nl/books?id=jtnQ7PIT8mcC&pg=PA308 Cat. no. 72] in ''Dutch Paintings in the Metropolitan Museum of Art'' Volume I, by [[Walter Liedtke]], Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2007</ref> Little is known of Haverman besides the biography of her written by [[Jan van Gool]].<ref name=Liedtke/> The only other work signed by her is in the [[Statens Museum for Kunst]]. In 1997 [[Delia Gaze]] remarked that this work was sold for 2100 francs to the MET and its pendant (now lost) was sold for 2050 francs.<ref>[https://books.google.nl/books?id=6_0Y0PALzQMC&pg=PA652 Haverman's MET painting] in [[Delia Gaze]]'s ''[[Dictionary of Women Artists]]''</ref> Blodgett must be credited with investing in the art of a woman, even if he let the pendant get away. Later curators must also be credited with keeping it, as only half of the 174 paintings are still in the collection.
==Description and interpretation== The work shows blooms of [[rosa × centifolia]], [[dianthus]], [[alcea rosea]], [[calendula officinalis]], [[passiflora]], [[primula]], [[papaver somniferum|poppy]], [[tulipa|tulip]], [[myosotis|forget-me-nots]], the fruits [[peach]] and [[grape]], and various insects such as a [[Vanessa atalanta|Red Admiral]], [[fly]], [[ant]]s, and a [[snail]].<ref name=RKD/> The vase itself is an object showing a baroque relief.<ref name=RKD/>
The painting follows in a tradition of Dutch and Flemish flower still life paintings showing flowers in a vase with insects. This was popular among Dutch women painters of Haverman's time whose works she would have been familiar with, as evidenced by the forged signature of [[Rachel Ruysch]] on a painting by [[Ottmar Elliger]] in the popular ''flowers in a vase on a ledge with insects'' style. This painting had been in the famous collection of [[Josephus Augustinus Brentano]] and was later purchased by [[Adriaan van der Hoop]] as by Ruysch.<ref>[http://collectie.amsterdammuseum.nl/amonline/advanced/Details/collect/38642 Stilleven met bloemen, 1673], [[Amsterdam Museum]] catalog</ref> The painting illustrates the model the women worked from, as well as the relative value of Ruysch's work over that of Elliger later in the 18th-century. Haverman was registered as a pupil of the flower painter [[Jan van Huysum]], who was known for guarding his secrets and keeping his painting knowledge in the family. This work shows the influence of Van Huysum in its "niche" setting. <gallery> File:Stilleven met bloemen Rijksmuseum SK-C-215.jpeg|Painting by Ottmar Elliger of 1673 that was later adorned with the forged signature of Ruysch File:Jan van Huysum - Vase of Flowers in a Niche SC226791.jpg|Painting by Jan van Huysum c. 1715 in the Museum of Fine Arts Boston that shows the same niche used by Haverman </gallery>
Comparable works by Haverman's compatriots were: <gallery> File:Stilleven met bloemen op een marmeren tafelblad Rijksmuseum SK-A-2338.jpeg|''[[Still life with flowers on a marble slab]]'', by Rachel Ruysch File:Catharina Backer - Flowers in a vase on a stone ledge.jpg|''Flowers in a vase on a stone ledge'', [[Catharina Backer]] File:Jacoba Maria van Nickelen - flowers in a vase set in a stone niche.jpeg|''Flowers in a vase set in a stone niche'', [[Jacoba Maria van Nickelen]] </gallery>
Possible followers of her technique were [[Francina Margaretha van Huysum]] and [[Cornelia van der Mijn]], whose green coloring appears to have faded to blue in the same way as the paintings of Backer and Haverman. This fading is possibly due to the use of a faded [[Stil de grain yellow|yellow lake pigment]].<ref name=Liedtke/> <gallery> File:Cornelia van der Mijn - flower still life.jpg|''Flower Still Life'', Cornelia van der Mijn File:Van Huysum, Michiel - A Delft Vase with Flowers - Google Art Project.jpg|''A Delft Vase with Flowers'', Francina Margaretha van Huysum </gallery>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1710s paintings]] [[Category:Paintings of the Metropolitan Museum of Art]] [[Category:Flower paintings]]

revision.text:
{{for|the 1987 book by Simon Schama|The Embarrassment of Riches: An Interpretation of Dutch Culture in the Golden Age}} {{infobox book | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Novels or Wikipedia:WikiProject_Books --> | name = An Embarrassment of Riches | title_orig = | translator = | image = An Embarassment of Riches by Charlson Ong bookcover.jpg | author = Charlson Ong | cover_artist = | country = [[Philippines]] | language = [[Philippine English|English]] | series = | genre = [[Novel]] | publisher = Philippine Centennial Commission, the University of the Philippines Press, and the UP Creative Writing Center | release_date = 2000 | media_type = Print | pages = 425 | isbn = 971-542-202-0 | isbn_note = | dewey= | congress= MLCM 2000/00356 (P) <ref name=OL>{{cite web|url=http://openlibrary.org/works/OL950342W/An_embarrassment_of_riches|title=An Embarrassment of Riches by Charlson Ong|publisher=Open Library|accessdate=4 July 2011}}</ref> | oclc= 45463617 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} {{italic title}} '''''An Embarrassment of Riches''''' is a 2000 novel written by Filipino novelist [[Charlson L. Ong]]. A Second Place Philippine Centennial Literary Prize winner, the novel was published in [[Quezon City]], [[Philippines]]<ref name=UPPress>{{cite web|url=http://uppress.com.ph/award.html|title=Awardwinning Titles|publisher=The University of the Philippines Press|accessdate=3 July 2011}}</ref><ref name=Cleto/> by the Philippine Centennial Commission, the University of the Philippines Press, and the UP Creative Writing Center, in celebration of the one hundred years of Philippine independence from Spain after the Philippine Revolution in 1898.<ref name=Cleto>{{cite web|url=http://journals.upd.edu.ph/index.php/humanitiesdiliman/article/view/1540/1487|title=The Mahjong of Power and Politics: A Reading Of Charlson Ong's 'Embarrassment of Riches' (''Ang Mahjong ng Kapangyarihan at Pulitika: Ang Binaong Alaala ng Tsina at Binuhay na Konsepto ng Nasyon, Isang Pagsipat sa 'Embarrassment of Riches' ni Charlson Ong'')|publisher=Humanities Diliman, Vol. 6, No. 1 and 2, 2009|first=Luna Sicat|last=Cleto|accessdate=4 July 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110623232837/http://journals.upd.edu.ph/index.php/humanitiesdiliman/article/view/1540/1487| archivedate= 23 June 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The 425-page novel was written in [[Philippine English]]. It is Charlson Ong’s first novel.<ref name=Pahl>{{cite web|url=http://www.palhbooks.com/groyon.htm|title=The metaphysical nation, Of love, nationalism, and other demons; Hopeful, not happy: The Centennial Literary Prize-winning novels in English, A Book Review|first=Vicente G|last=Groyon III|accessdate=2 July 2011|publisher=Philippine American Literary House|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927173731/http://www.palhbooks.com/groyon.htm|archive-date=2011-09-27|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
==Description== The scenes in ''An Embarrassment of Riches'' is set during the mid-1990s, and occurs in a fictional island west of the Philippines, known as the Victorianas. Victorianas is a "shadow of the Philippines" because it is a developing nation that has similarities to the Philippines. Although filled with characters, circumstances, and places that are familiar to Filipino readers, the Victorianas and the novel deviated from the real and contemporary life in the Philippines, and from the actual events in Philippine history. According to literary critic Vicente G. Groyon III, Ong’s fictionalization of recent Philippine history and recasting of the Philippines threads along the borders of [[surrealism]], providing the reader a sense of alienation, foreigness, or being ''not'' in the Philippines, despite of the similarity of the fictional Victorianas to the archipelago. Among the differences between Victorianas and the Philippines is that the Victorianas is an [[Americanize]]d Asian country where there is the absence or, even if present, has reduced influences from Spain and Europe, in terms of the Catholic religion, folk beliefs, and traditional practices. Victorianas is composed of [[mestizo]] or "hybrid" residents – including the descendants of Chinese, Japanese, Indian, and Malay ancestors, particularly the Chinese Filipinos. Ong intended ''An Embarrassment of Riches'' as a novel that presents a Southeast Asian perspective, rather than a Hispanic or Latin American viewpoint.<ref name=Pahl/> ''An Embarrassment of Riches'' is a political, [[thriller (genre)|thriller-filled]] [[whodunit]],<ref name=Geo/> and satirical work of fiction that serves as a parody to the events occurring in the Philippines, through the author’s creation and utilization of the imaginary island named Victorianas.<ref name=Pahl/>
==Characters== The main characters in ''An Embarrassment of Riches'' include Jeffrey Kennedy Tantivo, Jennifer Suarez (also known as JaySy or Jennifer Sy<ref name=Geo/>), General Azurin, Brother Mike Verano, and Alfonso Ong. Jeffrey Kennedy Tantivo is the hero and narrator in ''An Embarrassment of Riches''. Jennifer Suarez Sy, the "daughter of the richest man" in Victorianas,<ref name=Geo/> is a female politician who wanted to rule Victorianas by providing everything to her constituents. General Azurin is the dictator and ruler of Victorianas. Brother Mike Verano is a religious preacher with questionable background, the suspected killer of Tantivo's father.<ref name=Pahl/><ref name=Geo/> Alfonso Ong is another shady character, a wealthy and corrupt resident of Victorianas.<ref name=Pahl/>
==Plot==
In 1994,<ref name=Geo/> Jeffrey Kennedy Tantivo - a writer<ref name=Geo/> - returns from his exile in the Philippines<ref name=Panitikan>{{cite web|title=From 'An Embarrassment of Riches' by Charlson L. Ong, Part One |url=http://www.panitikan.com.ph/fiction/embarrassment-riches |publisher=Panitikan.com |accessdate=4 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928112837/http://www.panitikan.com.ph/fiction/embarrassment-riches |archivedate=28 September 2011 |df= }}</ref> to his homeland the Victorianas because of his father's death. Ong intends to uncover the identities of his father's murderers.<ref name=Geo>{{cite web|url=http://geocities.ws/centennialnovels/article.pdf|title=A Hundred Years after the Noli: The Three Centennial Novels in English|first=R. Kwan|last=Laurel|publisher=Geocities|accessdate=4 July 2011}}</ref> In addition to this circumstance, Tantivo was also summoned to return to Victorianas by his old friend Jennifer "JaySy" Suarez Sy. Sy – a middle aged woman belonging to the 20- to 30-year-old generation - wants Tantivo to manage her presidential campaign, timed after the demise of General Azurin, the dictatorial leader of Victorianas. Sy is a politician with Maoist inclinations. Sy won but her political rule was brief. On one hand, Brother Mike Verano (originally named as Damian Echevaria), a charismatic preacher and healer, leads the Victorianas Moral Restoration Army using violence for the cause of morality. Then, Alfonso Ong – a wealthy, shrewd and shady character – builds his alternative city of the future on an island off the coast of Victorianas. The novel ends with Tantivo leaving Victorianas – going back in exile – but with a renewed sense and sagacity after the altercations and travails he experienced in the island nation.<ref name=Pahl/> During Tantivo's stay in the Victoriana's, he found out that Jennifer Suarez is his half sister, and that his real father is Alfonso Ong. Tantivo left the Victorianas with Jennifer Suarez, leaving their beloved nation in political, socio-economic, and religious turmoil.<ref name=Geo/>
==Analysis== In ''An Embarrassment of Riches'', Ong employed [[metafiction]] to portray the Victorianas, a fictional country. Metafiction uses techniques to draw attention to itself as a work of art, while exposing the "truth" of a story. In the case of Ong, he used metafiction in ''An Embarrassment of Riches'' in order to draw attention to the novel as a work of literature and as a work of fiction, while exposing the realities happening in a non-fictional country - in this case the Philippines – represented by the Victorianas, an island monickered as a "little Philippines".<ref name=Cleto/> According to literary critic R. Kwan Laurel, Ong’s An Embarrassment of Riches is the most successful in inventing a fictional Philippines among the three 1989 Philippine Centennial Literary Prize winners (the other winning novels were [[Alfred Yuson]]'s ''[[Voyeurs & Savages]]'' and ''[[Eric Gamalinda|Eric Gamalinda's]]'' ''[[My Sad Republic]]''). Ong created an alternate country – one smaller than an archipelago, and with a different name – to represent the Philippines and its social, economic, and political situation and atmosphere. Because Ong is of [[Filipino Chinese|Chinese descent]], there was a possibility that the reader of ''''An Embarrassment of Riches'' can be interpreted as an "allegory of the Chinese gaining power – control and supremacy – in the Philippines".<ref name=Geo/>
The strength of ''An Embarrassment of Riches'' as a novel is that it did not "essentialize", simplify, and "exoticize" the Philippines (even if represented as the "Victorianas", the nation of the "Victorianos") and the Filipino experience. R. Kwan Laurel described the ending of ''An Embarrassment of Riches'' being similar to Filipino writer [[Nick Joaquin]]'s play the ''[[Portrait of an Artist as Filipino]]'', because Ong's hero pledges to survive, live, remember, and await for another opportunity, for the sake of all the people in the past.<ref name=Geo/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110928112837/http://www.panitikan.com.ph/fiction/embarrassment-riches Excerpt from Charlson L. Ong's ''An Embarrassment of Riches''] at the Philippine Literature Portal, Panitikan.com.ph

{{Infobox person |name = András Szántó |image = Andras Szanto in conversation with William Kentridge, Budapest Museum of Fine Arts, October 5, 2011.jpeg |image_size = |alt = |caption = Szanto in 2011 |birth_name = |birth_date = {{Birth date|1964|01|01}} |birth_place = Budapest |death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|1964|05|25}} --> |death_place = |body_discovered = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> |residence = New York City |nationality = |ethnicity = |citizenship = |other_names = |known_for = |education = |alma_mater = Columbia University, New York |employer = |occupation = |years_active = |home_town = |title = |term = |predecessor = |spouse = Alanna Stang |children = |parents = |relations = |callsign = |awards = |signature = |website = http://www.andras-szanto.com |footnotes = }}
'''András Szántó''' (b. Jan. 1, 1964, Budapest) is a writer, researcher, and consultant in the fields of art, media, cultural policy, arts sponsorship, and philanthropy, based in New York.
==Life and work==
After a childhood and early youth spent in Budapest and London, Szántó attended the Budapest University of Economics (now [[Corvinus University]]), and, in 1988, moved to New York for graduate studies in sociology. At [[Columbia University]], as a [http://pfl-css.columbia.edu/programs/lazarsfeld-fellowship-program.html Lazarsfeld Fellow], his research interests turned to the social and commercial ramifications of the visual arts. He completed his Ph.D. dissertation in 1996 on New York art galleries and the transformation of the art world in the 1980s, working closely with [[Arthur Danto]], the Columbia philosopher and art critic.
While in graduate school, Szántó worked as a research analyst at the Media Studies Center at Columbia. In the years 1997-2005, he was deputy directory and director of the [http://www.najp.org/%20 National Arts Journalism Program] at [http://www.journalism.columbia.edu Columbia ‘s Graduate School of Journalism], in association with the [http://arts.columbia.edu School of the Arts]. In 2005-10 he directed, also at Columbia, the NEA Arts Journalism Institute in Classical Music and Opera. Other appointments have included: research affiliate of the Center for Arts and Cultural Policy Studies at [[Princeton University]], visiting critic at the [[American Academy in Rome]], and senior visiting fellow at the [http://www.artsusa.org/information_services/research/cultural_policy_listserv/default.asp%20in%20Washington,%20DC Center for Arts and Culture in Washington, DC]. He is the Moderator of the [http://www.metmuseum.org/about-the-museum/press-room/news/2013/global-museum-leaders-colloquium Global Museum Leaders Colloquium] at the [http://www.metmuseum.org/ Metropolitan Museum of Art] In New York.
At Columbia, Szántó organized a [http://www.najp.org/events/conferences series of conferences] on a wide range of arts topics. Since 2008, he has moderated discussions of global museum leaders at [[Art Basel]] and [[Art Basel Miami Beach]], the [http://www.artdubai.ae/globalartforum Global Art Forum in Dubai], and other events. He was the curator of the September 2012 [http://artindustryforum.com International Art Industry Forum in Vienna], Austria. Szántó has taught courses on sociology at Columbia and [[Barnard College]], and on art business and marketing at the [http://www.sothebysinstitute.com/programmes/PNewyork.aspx Sotheby’s Institute of Art], New York. His principal professional focus is consulting and strategic advisory work with museums, foundations, cultural organizations, and corporations.
==Writing, Journalism, and Commentary==
Much of Szántó’s writing examines arts and cultural institutions, in particular the dynamics of the contemporary art world and art market. His journalism has appeared in [[The New York Times]], [[The Wall Street Journal]], [[Artforum]], [[The American Prospect]], I.D., Architecture, Print, Interiors, Men’s Vogue, [http://www.museumsassociation.org/museum-practice Museum Practice], and other publications. He is a contributing editor of [[The Art Newspaper]] and co-founder of [http://www.artworldsalon.com ArtworldSalon]. His writings and reports on the art world have explored topics ranging from the [http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Will-US-museums-succeed-in-reinventing-themselves?%20/20030 strategies], [http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Sixty-museums-in-search-of-a-purpose/25146 missions], and [http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/The-battles-over-but-does-the-new-Barnes-work/26496 architecture] of American art museums to the role of the arts in [http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Chinas-new-Age-of-Enlightenment/23495 cultural diplomacy], the [http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Funding-the-state-of-the-art-/20989 rhetoric of cultural advocacy], and the transformative role of [http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Time-to-lose-control/22092 technology in museums]. Earlier in his life, Szántó worked as a translator of art history and art criticism.
Szántó has also published widely on public affairs. In college, he researched the then-taboo topic of forced resettlements in Stalinist Hungary. In 1989, his undergraduate thesis became a bestselling book. In New York, he served as a correspondent for [http://magyarnarancs.hu Magyar Narancs], the first Hungarian alternative weekly, and published op-ed articles in [https://www.bostonglobe.com/ The Boston Globe] and [http://www.latimes.com/ The Los Angeles Times]. In 2007, he organized a conference, funded by Hungarian financier and philanthropist George [[George soros|Soros]], on political propaganda at the [http://www.mapdigital.com/orwell/welcome.html New York Public Library], and edited the companion book of essays, [http://www.publicaffairsbooks.com/publicaffairsbooks-cgi-bin/display?book=9781586485603 What Orwell Didn’t Know: Propaganda and the New Face of American Politics].
==Art, Business, and Strategy==
Szántó’s museum and foundation consulting involves the design and implementation of new programming and marketing initiatives, strategic planning, and the organization of conferences and public forums. He has also been retained by global corporations to design new arts engagement and sponsorship initiatives, including [https://www.artbasel.com/ Art Basel] and The Absolut Company / Pernod-Ricard, where he is the Principal Advisor to the [http://www.absolutartbureau.com/ Absolut Art Bureau]. He is the Chief Consultant of the [http://www.davidoffartinitiative.com/ Davidoff Art Initiative].
Past and present non-profit consulting clients have included The Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Guggenheim Foundation, [http://asiasociety.org/ Asia Society], The Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts, The Pew Charitable Trusts, The National Endowment for the Arts, The Museum of Fine Arts in Budapest, The Rockefeller Archive Center, The Henry Luce Foundation, The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, the RAND Corporation, the Rosenkranz Foundation, the Open Society Institute, the Aspen Institute, The Wallace Foundation, and The Robert Sterling Clark Foundation. Szántó regularly collaborates as a senior consultant with AEA Consulting, the New York arts advisory firm, where planning and evaluation clients have included The Public Art Fund, Tribeca Film Institute, The Museum of Contemporary Art in Detroit, SculptureCenter, The Meserve Kunhardt Foundation, the Roundabout Theater Company, the Knight Foundation, and the [http://www.gardnermuseum.org/ Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum].
==Cultural Policy, Diplomacy, and Philanthropy==
A former Senior Advisor to the Hungarian Minister of Culture and Education, Szántó has been active in the field of international cultural engagement. In 2001, he helped establish the Transatlantic Forum for Cultural Research at UNESCO in Paris. In 2003, he co-organized a Columbia University conference, [http://www.najp.org/publications/conferencereports/artsandminds.html Arts and Minds: Cultural Diplomacy Amid Global Tensions]. In 2012, he moderated a [http://www.salzburgglobal.org/home.html Salzburg Seminar], on Public and Private Cultural Exchange-Based Diplomacy: New Models for the 21st Century. Also in 2012, he participated in and wrote the summary report for the [http://asiasociety.org/files/pdf/USCH_MusDialogueReport.pdf Asia Society's US-China Museum Directors Forum in Beijing]. As an analyst and consultant in the field of private philanthropy, he contributed to the 2010 Aspen Institute report, [http://www.aspeninstitute.org/policy-work/nonprofit-philanthropy/Publications/The-Artist-as-Philanthropist The Artist as Philanthropist: Strengthening the Next Generation of Artist-endowed Foundations], and has served as an advisor to The Wealth & Giving Forum and the [http://www.rockarch.org Rockefeller Archive Center].
==Service and Family==
Szántó is the Chair of the Visiting Committee of the [http://www.sfai.edu San Francisco Art Institute] and has served on the advisory boards of [http://www.apexart.org Apexart], [http://www.allianceforarts.org The Alliance for the Arts], [http://www.gordonparksfoundation.org the Gordon Parks Foundation], the [http://www.scps.nyu.edu/areas-of-study/philanthropy-fundraising George H. Heyman Center for Philanthropy at NYU], and the research advisory committee of the [http://www.cpanda.org/cpanda CPANDA] (Cultural Policy and the Arts National Data Archive) at Princeton. He lives in New York City with his wife, Alanna Stang, a magazine editor and author on [http://www.papress.com/html/book.details.page.tpl?isbn=9781568989501 sustainable architecture], and their sons, Alexander and Hugo.
