[[File:San Francisco Womens Building.jpg|thumb|San Francisco Women's Building]] [[File:Front Women's Building.jpg|thumb|Front Women's Building]] [[File:Women's Building Side detail.jpg|thumb|Women's Building Side detail]] '''Miranda Bergman''' is a contemporary muralist and one of the seven women artists who in 1994 created the ''[[MaestraPeace]]'' mural,<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.pbs.org/independentlens/newamericans/culturalriches/slide01.html|title = PBS: The New Americans|date = |accessdate = March 7, 2014|website = PBS|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> the largest mural in San Francisco, which covers [[The Women's Building]].
== Work == She grew up in the [[Mission District, San Francisco|San Francisco Mission District]] and attended [[Balboa High School (California)|Balboa High School]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hoke|first1=Mateo|title=Painters Scale Women’s Building to Restore the "MaestraPeace" Mural|url=http://missionlocal.org/2012/09/painters-scale-womens-building-to-restore-the-maestrapeace-mural/|work=MissionLocal|date=September 13, 2012}}</ref> She now lives in Oakland.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Garcia|first1=Janelle|title=The Last Mural Standing|url=http://xpress.sfsu.edu/xpressmagazine/2014/12/11/the-last-mural-standing/|accessdate=8 March 2015|work=Xpress Magazine|date=Fall 2014}}</ref>
In the 1970s, she joined other artists in the [[Haight-Ashbury]] Muralists.<ref name="Barnett">{{cite book|last1=Barnett|first1=Alan|title=Community murals: the people's art|date=1984|publisher=Philadelphia : Art Alliance Press ; New York : Cornwall Books|url=https://archive.org/details/communitymuralsp00barnrich|accessdate=9 March 2015}}</ref> From 1972 to 1976 Bergman created labor-themed posters with Jane Nordling for the Working Peoples' Artists collective.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Goldman|first1=Shifra M.|title=Dimensions of the Americas: Art and Social Change in Latin America and the United States|date=1994|publisher=Univ. of Chicago Press|location=Chicago|isbn=0-226-30124-9|page=175|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kOvD9spwwDQC&lpg=PA175&dq=%22Miranda%20Bergman%22&pg=PA175#v=onepage&q&f=false|chapter=A Public Voice: Fifteen Years of Chicano Posters}}</ref> She worked on a [[CETA]] funded project with other artists to paint murals in the city jail.<ref name="Barnett" />
In 1986, Bergman worked with [[Juana Alicia]], Hector Noel Méndez, Ariella Seidenberg, and Arch Williams to create the mural ''El Amancer'' (''The Dawn'') in a park in [[Managua]], Nicaragua.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Blandy|first1=Doug E.|last2=Congdon|first2=Kristin G., eds.|title=Pluralistic Approaches to Art Criticism|date=1991|publisher=Popular Press|isbn=0879725443}}</ref><ref name="Alicia">{{cite web|last1=Alicia|first1=Juana|title=Remembering the Mission: A Reflection|url=http://www.juanaalicia.com/content/remembering-the-mission-a-reflection/|website=Juana Alicia|accessdate=March 11, 2015}}</ref> Bergman and Alicia completed part of the work in the middle of the night, guarded by armed teenagers and "working in spite of the threat of a U.S.-backed Contra attack."<ref name="Alicia" />
Her South Africa-themed photo collage was included in the [[Syracuse Cultural Workers]]' 1987 calendar.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Teaching Resources: Colorful catalog|journal=Feminist Teacher|date=1986|volume=2|issue=2|page=44|jstor=40545510|publisher=University of Illinois Press}}</ref>
She worked and lived in the Palestinian city of [[Ramallah]] for nine weeks in 1989 with three other Jewish-American women artists and teachers as part of the Break the Silence mural project.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Painting for Peace: Break the Silence Mural Project|journal=Bridges|date=Fall 1990|volume=1|issue=2|pages=39, 40|jstor=40358476|publisher=Bridges Association}}</ref> The mural they created together is in the Popular Arts Center in Ramallah, Palestine.<ref>{{cite web|title=Palestinian Women Nurturing the Intifada|url=http://www.palestineposterproject.org/poster/palestinian-women-nurturing-the-intifada|website=The Palestine Poster Project Archives|accessdate=March 11, 2015}}</ref> Bergman's poster ''Tribute to Palestinian Women'' was included in the 1989-1990 traveling exhibition ''In Celebration of the State of Palestine'' and is now part of the digital collection of The Palestine Poster Project Archives.<ref>{{cite web|title=In Celebration of the State of Palestine/La Pena (Press Sheet)|url=http://www.palestineposterproject.org/poster/in-celebration-of-the-state-of-palestinela-pena-press-sheet|website=The Palestine Poster Project Archive.|accessdate=March 11, 2015}}</ref>
In 1994 she co-created "The Culture Contains the Seed of Resistance That Blossoms into the Flower of Liberation" with O’Brien Thiele, the last intact mural among the famed Placa murals of [[Balmy Alley]] in San Francisco.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.sfgate.com/art/article/Historical-Mission-mural-s-message-still-vivid-5742769.php|title = Mission District mural fades after 30 years, but message doesn't|date = September 9, 2014|accessdate = March 7, 2015|work=San Francisco Chronicle |last =Jones |first =Carolyn }}</ref> This mural depicts a naturally beautiful landscape contrasted against women holding photographs of ''[[desaparecidos]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cordova|first1=Cary|title=The Heart of the Mission: Latino Art and Identity in San Francisco|url=https://www.lib.utexas.edu/etd/d/2005/cordovad06814/cordovad06814.pdf|publisher=University of Texas at Austin|accessdate=8 March 2015|page=318|date=December 2005}}</ref>
Bergman has also worked on other murals in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wolfe|first1=Eli|title=The It List: 5 things to do in Berkeley this weekend|url=http://www.berkeleyside.com/2013/10/10/the-it-list-5-things-to-do-in-berkeley-this-weekend-4/|accessdate=8 March 2015|publisher=Berkeleyside|date=10 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Pimentel|first1=Benjamin|title=Kenyan Nobel Peace Prize winner linking arms with Filipino hero|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/13871/kenyan-nobel-peace-prize-winner-linking-arms-with-filipino-hero/|accessdate=8 March 2015|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=27 September 2011}}</ref> In the 1990s, Bergman was also a consulting editor of ''[[Frontiers: A Journal of Women Studies]]''.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Front Matter|journal=Frontiers: A Journal of Women Studies|date=1991|volume=12|jstor=3346638}}</ref>
Bergman participated in the May, 2017 San Francisco SOMArts Cultural Center's exhibition, "Shifting Movements: Art Inspired by the Life and Activism of [[Yuri Kochiyama]] (1921-2014)."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rafu.com/2017/04/exhibition-of-art-inspired-by-yuri-kochiyama/|title=Exhibition of Art Inspired by Yuri Kochiyama|website=www.rafu.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-05}}</ref>

{{Distinguish|Monogram}}
A '''monograph''' is a specialist work of writing (in contrast to [[reference work]]s)<ref>{{cite book |author1=Campbell |first1=Robert |last2=Pentz |first2=Ed |last3=Borthwick |first3=Ian |date=2012 |title=Academic and Professional Publishing |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IpRlAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA115#v=onepage&q&f=false |isbn=978-1-78063-309-1 |quote='[M]onograph' has become a catch-all term for a book that is not of a reference type, that is of primary material}}.</ref> on a single subject or an aspect of a subject, often by a single author, and usually on a scholarly subject.
In library cataloging, ''monograph'' has a broader meaning, that of a nonserial publication complete in one [[Volume (bibliography)|volume]] (book) or a definite number of volumes. Thus it differs from a [[periodical publication|serial]] publication such as a [[magazine]], [[academic journal|journal]], or [[newspaper]].<ref>Prytherch, Raymond John, ''Harrod's librarians' glossary and reference book: a directory of over 10,200 terms, organizations, projects and acronyms in the areas of information management, library science, publishing and archive management'', 10th edn (Aldershot, Hants, England ; Burlington, VT: Ashgate, 2005), p. 462.; "For the purpose of library cataloging, any nonserial publication, complete in one volume or intended to be completed in a finite number of parts issued at regular or irregular intervals, containing a single work or collection of works. Monographs are sometimes published in monographic series and subseries. Compare with book."[http://www.abc-clio.com/ODLIS/odlis_m.aspx#monograph]</ref> In this context only, books such as [[novel]]s are monographs.__FORCETOC__
== In academia == {{See also|Monographic series}} The term "monographia" is derived from the Greek "mono" (single) and ''grapho'' (to write), meaning "writing on a single subject".<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.phytojournal.com/archives/?year=2018&vol=7&issue=4&ArticleId=5296&si=false |title=Development of monograph and study of variation in chemical constituent of plant Balanites roxburghii |journal=Journal of Pharmacognosy and Phytochemistry |volume=7 |issue=4 |year=2018 |access-date=8 October 2018 |pages=2369-2371}}</ref> Unlike a textbook, which surveys the state of knowledge in a field, the main purpose of a monograph is to present primary research and original scholarship ascertaining reliable credibility to the required recipient. This research is presented at length, distinguishing a monograph from an article. For these reasons, publication of a monograph is commonly regarded as vital for career progression in many academic disciplines. Intended for other researchers and bought primarily by libraries, monographs are generally published as individual volumes in a short print run.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1108/00012530910932294 |title=The role and future of the monograph in arts and humanities research|journal=Aslib Proceedings |volume=61 |pages=67 |year=2009 |last1=Williams |first1=Peter |last2=Stevenson|first2=Iain|last3=Nicholas|first3=David|last4=Watkinson|first4=Anthony|last5=Rowlands|first5=Ian}}</ref>
In Britain and the U.S., what differentiates a scholarly monograph from an academic trade title varies by publisher, though generally it is the assumption that the readership has not only specialized or sophisticated knowledge but also professional interest in the subject of the work.<ref>{{cite book |last=Thompson |first=John B. |title=Books in the Digital Age: The Transformation of Academic and Higher Education Publishing in Britain and the United States |publisher=Polity Press |location=Cambridge |year=2005 |isbn=978-0745634784 |pages=84-85}}</ref>
== In art == Book publishers use the term "artist monograph" to indicate books dealing with a single artist, as opposed to broader surveys of art subjects.
== In biology ==
In biological taxonomy a monograph is a comprehensive treatment of a [[taxon]]. Monographs typically review all known species within a group, add any newly discovered species, and collect and synthesize available information on the ecological associations, geographic distributions, and morphological variations within the group. See this reference as an example.<ref>{{cite journal |date=|title=Revision of the Triatominae (Hemiptera, Reduviidae), and their significance as vectors of Chagas' disease |url=https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/bibliography/89400#/summary |journal=Bulletin of the American Museum of Natural History|volume=163|issue=3|pages=125-520|hdl=2246/1282 |author1=Lent, Herman |author2=Wygodzinsky, Pedro W.}}</ref>
The first-ever monograph of a plant taxon was [[Robert Morison]]'s 1672 ''Plantarum Umbelliferarum Distributio Nova'', a treatment of the [[Apiaceae]].<ref name="Vines 1913">{{cite book | author = [[Sydney Howard Vines|Vines, Sydney Howard]] | year = 1913 | chapter = Robert Morison 1620–1683 and John Ray 1627–1705 | editor = [[Francis Wall Oliver|Oliver, Francis Wall]] (ed.) | title = Makers of British Botany | publisher = Cambridge University Press | page = 22}}</ref>
== In United States Food and Drug Administration regulation == {{See also|Pharmacopoeia}} In the context of [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) regulation, monographs represent published standards by which the use of one or more substances is automatically authorized. For example, the following is an excerpt from the ''[[Federal Register]]'': "The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is issuing a final rule in the form of a final monograph establishing conditions under which over-the-counter (OTC) sunscreen drug products are [[generally recognized as safe and effective]] and not misbranded as part of FDA's ongoing review of OTC drug products."<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.fda.gov/OHRMS/DOCKETS/98fr/052199b.txt |work=Federal Register|date= May 21, 1999 |volume= 64|number= 98 |series=Rules and Regulations |pages=27666–27693|title=DOCID:fr21my99-6}}</ref> Such usage has given rise to the use of the word monograph as a verb, as in "this substance has been monographed by the FDA".

[[Alan Heim]] | studio = Curmudgeon Films | distributor = [[New Line Cinema]] | released = {{Film date|2009|6|26}} | runtime = 109 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $30 million | gross = $95.7 million }} '''''My Sister's Keeper''''' is a 2009 American [[drama film]] directed by [[Nick Cassavetes]] and starring [[Cameron Diaz]], [[Abigail Breslin]], [[Sofia Vassilieva]], [[Jason Patric]], and [[Alec Baldwin]]. Based on [[Jodi Picoult]]'s [[My Sister's Keeper (novel)|2004 novel of the same name]],{{cite web | date=February 12, 2008 | title=Breslin, Vassilieva to star in 'Keeper'. Duo replaces Fanning sisters in New Line film | url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117980824.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 | first= Michael | last=Fleming | work=Variety | accessdate=February 13, 2008}} on June 26, 2009 the film was released to cinemas in the [[United States]],{{cite web|title=My Sister's Keeper (2009)|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=mysisterskeeper.htm|publisher=Box Office Mojo|accessdate=January 12, 2012}} [[Canada]], [[Ireland]], [[Mexico]], and the [[United Kingdom]]. ==Plot== Kate Fitzgerald ([[Sofia Vassilieva]]) has [[acute promyelocytic leukemia]]. Conceived by [[in vitro fertilization]], her younger sister Anna ([[Abigail Breslin]]) was brought into the world as a [[Savior sibling|savior sister]]. She is a genetic match to her older sister and can donate compatible organs, blood, and tissue to help her. When Kate turns 15, she goes into [[renal failure]] and 11-year old Anna knows that she will be forced by her parents to donate one of her kidneys. She also realizes that she may not be able to live the life she wants to lead – she will not be able to play sports, drink alcohol, or be a mother in the future. Anna tells her parents that she does not want to be a donor and sues them for [[medical emancipation]] and the rights to her own body. Her father Brian ([[Jason Patric]]) understands her, though her domineering mother, Sara ([[Cameron Diaz]]), who leads an obsessive campaign to keep Kate alive, is indignant at her decision. Attorney Campbell Alexander ([[Alec Baldwin]]) agrees to work for Anna as her guardian [[ad litem]], suing for partial termination of [[Parents' rights movement|parental rights]]. He has agreed to take the case because he has [[epilepsy]], and is sympathetic to her predicament. The film is interlaced with flashbacks that detail Kate and Anna's close relationship, as well as how Kate's illness has affected her siblings, including their brother, Jesse (Evan Ellingson). In a flashback, Kate meets a fellow cancer patient, Taylor Ambrose ([[Thomas Dekker (actor)|Thomas Dekker]]), whom she begins dating. He asks her to the hospital's prom for teen patients; there, they slow-dance, then have sex. A few days later, Kate begins to worry as she has not seen Taylor since the dance. She learns that Taylor has died and attempts suicide by overdosing on painkillers, but Anna stops her. Kate expresses hope that after she dies, she will see Taylor. Kate makes a request to go to the beach one last time. Brian obtains permission and discharges her from the hospital for the day. Sara overreacts and demands that Kate be returned to the hospital immediately. Brian angrily refuses and threatens Sara with a divorce if she does not join them. Sara shows up at the beach, where they enjoy one final family outing. During the hearing, Jesse reveals that Anna is actually acting under Kate's instruction; Kate, not wanting to live any longer, had persuaded Anna to refuse to donate her kidney. Anna had wanted to give Kate her kidney and had been upset at Kate's decision. Sara is finally forced to acknowledge what Kate has been trying to tell her all this time: she is ready to die. Later that day, Kate dies sleeping, with her mother by her side. After her death, Campbell states that Anna has won the case. The family moves on with their lives. Sara, who gave up practicing law to look after Kate, returns to work, Brian retires from firefighting and counsels troubled youths, and Jesse receives an arts scholarship in New York. Anna reveals that every year on Kate's birthday they go to [[Montana]], which was her "most favorite place in the world". She concludes that she was not born merely to save her sister, she was born because she had a sister, and that their relationship continues even in death. ==Production and cast changes== Upon the original creation of the film adaptation, sisters [[Dakota Fanning]] and [[Elle Fanning]] were cast to play Kate and Anna respectively. However, when Dakota heard that she would be required to shave her head for the role, she dropped out of the film as then did Elle. The two sisters were replaced, with [[Abigail Breslin]] taking on the lead role as Anna Fitzgerald and [[Sofia Vassilieva]] on the role of Kate Fitzgerald.{{cite web|title=Dakota Fanning Steps Down From 'My Sister's Keeper' Role|url=http://www.starpulse.com/news/index.php/2008/02/13/dakota_fanning_steps_down_from_my_sister|publisher=Starpulse.com|accessdate=January 12, 2012|date=February 13, 2008}} ==Cast== * [[Abigail Breslin]] as Anna Fitzgerald ** Alexandra Casteele as Young Anna Fitzgerald * [[Cameron Diaz]] as Sara Fitzgerald * [[Sofia Vassilieva]] as Kate Fitzgerald ** Olivia Hancock as young Kate Fitzgerald * [[Jason Patric]] as Brian Fitzgerald * Chris Kinkade as Dr. Nguyen * [[David Thornton (actor)|David Thornton]] as Dr. Chance * Evan Ellingson as Jesse Fitzgerald ** [[Brennan Bailey]] as young Jesse Fitzgerald ** Paul Christopher Butler as three-year-old Jesse * [[Alec Baldwin]] as Campbell Alexander * [[Elizabeth Daily|E.G. Daily]] as Nurse Susan * [[Lin Shaye]] as Nurse Adele * [[Joan Cusack]] as Judge De Salvo * [[Heather Wahlquist]] as Kelly * [[Thomas Dekker (actor)|Thomas Dekker]] as Taylor Ambrose * [[Emily Deschanel]] as Dr. Farquad ==Reception== ===Critical response=== The film received mixed reviews from critics. [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reports that 47% of reviews for the film were positive, based on 126 reviews.{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/10010662-my_sisters_keeper/|title=My Sister's Keeper|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=December 7, 2009}} Another aggregate review site [[Metacritic]] reported 51% positive reviews based on 28 reviews.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/film/titles/mysisterskeeper|title=My Sister's Keeper (2009): Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]]}} ===Box office=== In its opening weekend it placed 5th with a total of $12,442,212, behind ''[[Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen]]'', ''[[The Proposal (2009 film)|The Proposal]]'' (second weekend), ''[[The Hangover (film)|The Hangover]]'' (fourth weekend), and ''[[Up (2009 film)|Up]]'' (fifth weekend).{{cite web|title=Weekend Box Office Results for June 26–28, 2009|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?view=&yr=2009&wknd=26&p=.htm|publisher=Box Office Mojo|accessdate=January 12, 2012}} The film left theatres on October 8, 2009 with a domestic total of $49,200,230 with a further $46,459,927 from foreign markets. It has grossed $95,660,157 worldwide. ===Awards=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Award ! Category ! Recipient ! Daily]] – "[[Life Is Just a Bowl of Cherries]]" * [[Priscilla Ahn]] – "Find My Way Back Home" * [[Jimmy Scott]] – "Heaven" * [[Regina Spektor]] – "Better" * Jonah Johnson – "With You" * [[Greg Laswell]] – "[[Girls Just Want to Have Fun]]" * [[Pete Yorn]] – "Don't Wanna Cry" * [[Phil X]]enidis – "Kill Me" * [[Jeff Buckley]] – "We All Fall in Love Sometimes" * [[Edwina Hayes]] – "[[Feels Like Home (Randy Newman song)|Feels Like Home]]" * [[Hana Pestle]] – "These Two Hands" ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.mysisterskeepermovie.com/}} * {{IMDb title|1078588}} * {{mojo title|mysisterskeeper}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes|10010662-my_sisters_keeper}} * [http://www.tvmoviesongs.com/movies/my-sisters-keeper-soundtrack My Sister's Keeper Soundtrack] {{Nick Cassavetes}} {{Organ transplantation in fiction}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:My Sister's Keeper (Film)}} [[Category:2009 films]] [[Category:2000s drama films]] [[Category:2000s legal films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American legal drama films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films about cancer]] [[Category:Films about death]] [[Category:Films about dysfunctional families]] [[Category:Films about lawyers]] [[Category:Films about sisters]] [[Category:Films based on works by Jodi Picoult]] [[Category:Films directed by Nick Cassavetes]] [[Category:Films set in California]] :Abigail Breslin/Sofia Vassilieva/Olivia Hancock/Alexandra Casteele/Olivia Jade Fine Childstarlets.Com My Sister's Keeper

[[File:PLM at Grunwick march.jpg|thumb|'''PLM at Grunwick march (1977)''']] The '''People’s Liberation Music''' (PLM) was a political music group, playing folk and agit-pop, founded in 1972 by [[Laurie Scott Baker]], [[John Marcangelo]] and [[John Tilbury]]. After Tilbury left in 1973 [[Cornelius Cardew]] and [[Keith Rowe]] joined with Vicky Silva as the main vocalist.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Keith Rowe|last=Olewnick|first=Brian|publisher=Powerhouse Books|year=2018|isbn=978-1576878644|location=|pages=223-227}}</ref> Other members included [[Hugh Shrapnel]], and [[Dave Smith (composer)|Dave Smith]]; among its many drummers were [[Pip Pyle]], John Mitchell, [[Back Door (jazz trio)|Tony Hicks]] and John Hewitt. After the group was dissolved in 1978 it was followed by the Progressive Cultural Association (PCA).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bl.uk/eblj/2013articles/pdf/ebljarticle42013.pdf|title=Cornelius Cardew’s Music for Moving Images: Some Preliminary Observations|last=Gresser|first=Clemens|date=|website=The British Library|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The album "We Only Want The Earth" (Musicnow – MNCDx004) was released in 2001.

{{For|the Stephen King novel and related articles|Pet Sematary (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}} [[File:Hartsdale Canine Cemetery October 2012.jpg|thumb|250px|Hartsdale Canine Cemetery]] [[File:Pet Cemetery -San Francisco-3.jpg|thumb|Pet cemetery in San Francisco, California]] [[File:Pguggenheimgrave.jpg|thumb|Grave of Peggy Guggenheim next to a plaque remembering her dogs]]
A '''pet cemetery''' is a [[cemetery]] for animals.
==History== [[File:Hiran Minar- monument to Mansraj.jpg|thumb|The ''[[Hiran Minar]]'' near [[Lahore]], [[Pakistan]] was built in the early 17th century by the [[Mughal empire|Mughal]] Emperor [[Jahangir]] in honor of his beloved pet deer.]] Many human cultures [[burial|buried]] animal remains. For example, the [[Ancient Egypt]]ians [[Mummy|mummified]] and buried [[cat]]s, which they considered [[deity|deities]], and [[Ashkelon dog cemetery|the largest known dog cemetery in the ancient world]] was discovered at the [[Ashkelon National Park]] in [[Ashkelon]], [[Israel]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bib-arch.org/e-features/dogs-buried-at-ashkelon.asp |title=Why are hundreds of dogs buried at Ashkelon|website=bib-arch.org}} </ref>
London's [[Hyde Park, London|Hyde Park]] was the site of an informal pet cemetery between 1881 and 1903, in the gatekeeper's garden.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.funlondontours.com/news/victorian-pet-cemetery-hyde-park |title=The Victorian Pet Cemetery of Hyde Park|website=Fun London Tours}}</ref> From the first burial of "Cherry" until its official closure in 1903, it received 300 burials with miniature headstones,<ref>[http://londoninsight.wordpress.com/2010/10/06/pet-cemetery-hyde-park/ The Pet Cemetery of Hyde Park] London insight Blog, 6 October 2010</ref> with a final special burial of the [[Royal Marines]] mascot dog "Prince" in 1967.<ref>[http://london365.co.uk/hyde-park-pet-cemetery Hyde Park Pet Cemetery] London 365, 11 November 2012</ref>
[[Cimetière des Chiens]] in [[Asnières-sur-Seine]] in [[Paris, France|Paris]], dating from 1899, is an elaborate, sculpted pet cemetery believed to be one of the first public [[zoology|zoological]] [[necropolis]] in the world.<ref>[http://www.lostandfond.co.uk/news-features/2010-08/tour-parisian-pet-cemetery-cimetiere-du-chiens A tour of Parisian pet cemetery Cimetière des Chiens] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222084040/http://www.lostandfond.co.uk/news-features/2010-08/tour-parisian-pet-cemetery-cimetiere-du-chiens |date=22 February 2012 }}</ref>
America's largest and oldest pet cemetery is in [[Hartsdale, New York]]. It dates from 1896, when a veterinarian working out of [[Manhattan]] offered to let a grieving pet owner bury her dog in his hillside apple orchard. Today, it is the final resting place for more than 70,000 animals.<ref>[http://www.lostandfond.co.uk/news-features/2010-12/apple-orchard-became-new-yorks-famous-hartsdale-pet-cemtery Apple orchard that became New York's famous Hartsdale Pet Cemetery]</ref> The [[Hartsdale Pet Cemetery]] was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 2012.<ref name="nps">{{cite web|url=http://www.cr.nps.gov/nr/listings/20120824.htm|title=National Register of Historic Places Listings|date=2012-08-24|work=Weekly List of Actions Taken on Properties: 8/13/12 through 8/17/12 |publisher=National Park Service}}</ref> Some other famous American pet cemeteries are Aspin Hill Memorial Park in [[Silver Spring, Maryland]], where celebrity animals such as seven of [[J. Edgar Hoover]]'s dogs, such as his Cairn terrier Spee De Bozo,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/1827|work=Find a Grave|title=Spee De Bozo|accessdate=June 13, 2016}}</ref> and internees at the "Medical Rats Memorial" are buried. (General Grant of R.K.O. was rumored to be Petey of the Our Gang and Little Rascals movies, but this is not true);<ref>{{cite web|website=Roadside America|url= http://www.roadsideamerica.com/story/3626|title=Grave of a Petey, Little Rascals Dog|accessdate=June 15, 2016}}</ref> as well as the Pet Memorial Cemetery in [[Calabasas, CA]], where [[Hopalong Cassidy]]'s horse, Topper, [[Steven Spielberg]]'s [[Jack Russell Terrier]], and [[Rudolph Valentino]]'s dog, Kabar, are buried.<ref>{{cite web|website=Roadside America|url= http://www.roadsideamerica.com/story/3626|title=Grave of a Petey, Little Rascals Dog|accessdate=June 15, 2016}}</ref>
==Burial options== At some cemeteries, such as Aspin Hill Memorial Park in [[Silver Spring, Maryland]]<ref>{{cite web|website=Roadside America|url= http://www.roadsideamerica.com/story/3626|title=Grave of a Petey, Little Rascals Dog|accessdate=June 15, 2016}}</ref> human and animal remains may be interred alongside each other. In January 2010, West Lindsey District Council gave permission for a site in the village of [[Stainton by Langworth]] to inter animal remains alongside human remains as part of a "[[Natural burial|green burial]]" site, making it the first place in England where pets could be buried alongside their owners.<ref>[http://www.express.co.uk/posts/view/153754/Pet-lovers-can-be-buried-with-their-animals "Pet lovers can be buried with their animals"], [[Daily Express|Sunday Express]], accessed 25 January 2010</ref>
==See also== *[[Animal loss]] *[[Pet Sematary]]

{{orphan|date=May 2015}} ''Reverse Television'' is a series of forty-four video portraits made by [[United States|American]] [[video artist]] [[Bill Viola]] in 1983, originally produced for [[broadcast television]] and later documented as a 15-minute video. These portraits depict people throughout [[Boston]] sitting in their living rooms, silently staring at the video camera as though it were a TV set.{{cite web|url=http://www.eai.org/title.htm?id=701|title=Reverse Television -- Portraits of Viewers (Compilation Tape)|website=Electronic Arts Intermix}} The portraits were meant to take fit into the space normally occupied by television commercials and as such to "interrupt the continuity of the undifferentiated flow of the television picture, giving viewers the possibility of pondering their own position facing the screen."{{cite web|last1=Moisdon|first1=Stéphanie|title=Reverse Television - Portraits of Viewers|url=http://www.newmedia-art.org/cgi-bin/show-oeu.asp?ID=150000000034594&lg=GBR|website=New Media Encyclopedia}} == Background == "Reverse Television" was first broadcast by [[WGBH-TV]] In an interview with [[Raymond Bellour]], Bill Viola describes the compromises he had to negotiate through in the making and initial distribution of "Reverse Television."{{cite journal|last1=Bellour|first1=Raymond|title=An Interview with Bill Viola|journal=T|date=Autumn 1985|volume=34|pages=91–119}} Originally, Viola wanted the video portraits to be presented once every hour for a two-week period in one-minute segments with "no label, no title, or anything" attached to them. Viola claims that such a long duration as well as an absence of identifying information was crucial to the piece, since the work was meant to be a disruption of the normal viewing experience of television. WGBH-TV, wishing to keep broadcasting costs low, wanted to show the portraits in fifteen-second segments. The station also refused to broadcast the videos without a title, requesting that Viola include a full description of the piece at the beginning of each clip. In a confrontation with the station director, Viola ultimately agreed to show the clips in thirty second segments with text at the end of each clip stating his name and the date. == Video Summary == The 1984 documentation of the project begins with text describing the project:{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4GrIN9m83zw|title=reverse television.mov|website=Youtube}}
REVERSE TELEVISION is a project for broadcast television. A series of portrait recordings were made of people sitting in their homes, staring in silence at the camera. Forty four portraits were made in the Boston area with subjects ranging in age from 16 to 93 years old. Ten continuous minutes were recorded with each person. An unbroken 1 minute segment of this material was to be broadcast. The portraits would be shown each hour of the broadcast day as image inserts between programs. They would appear unannounced, with no titles before or after, and the series would run for several weeks. WGBH TV Boston presented REVERSE TELEVISION from NOV. 14-28, 1983. They chose to air the portraits for 30 seconds each, showing them 5 times a day. The following is a series of 15 second excerpts from all of the portraits. They are presented in the order they were recorded and represent a documentation of this project.

{{italic title}} [[File:Tríptico de Santa Columba, Roger van der Weyden.jpg|thumb|600px|[[Rogier van der Weyden]]'s ''St Columba Altarpiece''. Oil on oak panel, 138 x 70 cm, 138 x 153 cm, 138 x 70. [[Alte Pinakothek]], Munich]]
The '''''Saint Columba Altarpiece''''' (sometimes '''''Adoration of the Kings''''') is a large c. 1455 oil-on-oak wood [[panel painting|panel]] [[altarpiece]] by [[Early Netherlandish painting|Early Netherlandish]] painter [[Rogier van der Weyden]], now in the [[Alte Pinakothek]], Munich.<ref name = "Campbell">Campbell (1980), 74</ref>
The three panels depict a narrative in which [[Mary (mother of Jesus)|Mary]] is visited by the [[Annunciation|archangel Gabriel]]; she [[Nativity of Jesus|gives birth in a stable]], and she [[Presentation of Jesus at the Temple|presents the infant at the temple]]. The left wing shows the [[Annunciation]], the center depicts the [[Adoration of the Magi]] after [[Jesus|Christ]]'s birth, and the [[Presentation of Jesus at the Temple|Presentation in the Temple]] appears on the right wing.<ref name = "Campbell"/>
==Panels==
[[File:Rogier van der Weyden 008.jpg|thumb|upright|left|The Annunication panel]] The elegant Annunciation is filled with iconography, such as the faux carving of the [[fall of man]] on the side of the [[prie-dieu]] at which Mary kneels in her devotions. An old-fashioned cross hangs over her head in the center panel's Nativity scene; the donor is placed on the far left, and a sweeping landscape can be seen in the background.<ref name = "Campbell"/> The center panel's far right contains the exterior of the same building shown in the next scene from the inside, juxtaposing the stable with the temple and thereby causing an innovative yet jarring spatial and temporal juxtaposition. The stable is in [[Bethlehem]], the Temple in [[Jerusalem]], yet here they co-exist and function to bridge a gap from the [[Old Testament|Old]] to the [[New Testament]]. It the first Early Netherlandish painting where the building's exterior exists on one panel and its interior on the adjacent panel. Van der Weyden achieved an extremely innovative means of moving a narrative in a continuous fashion in this altarpiece. The Presentation occurs in the octagonal building's [[narthex]], surrounded by monumental arches, another bold and innovative use of space and perspective.<ref name = "Borchert87" />
The exterior panels on the reverse are covered with plain paint without evidence that they ever contained a [[donor portrait]]. The donor is positioned on the far left of the center panel.<ref name = "Campbell"/>
''Saint Columba altarpiece'' was the object of frequent copying in the 15th and 16th centuries,<ref name = "Campbell"/> and inspired some of [[Hans Memling]]'s works, among them the ''[[Triptych of Jan Floreins]]''.<ref name = "Borchert87">Borchert, 87</ref> {{clear}}
==Commission==
The altarpiece was included as part of the 1801 inventory of [[Cologne]]'s Saint Columba cathedral, where it resided in the von dem Wasservass family chapel, which was probably established in the 1460s by Goddert von dem Wasservass, burgomaster of Cologne. It is reasonable to assume such a prominent resident of the city commissioned the piece. According to [[Lorne Campbell (Art historian)|Lorne Campbell]], based on the number of known copies, the piece probably never left the private chapel until 1801. [[Sulpiz Boisserée|Sulpiz]] and [[Melchior Boisserée|Melchior]] Boisseree bought it in 1808; their collection was acquired in 1827 for the [[Alte Pinakothek]] in Munich.<ref name = "Campbell"/>
==Citations== {{reflist}} {{commons category|Category:Adoration of the Magi by Rogier van der Weyden}} ==Sources== * [[Till-Holger Borchert|Borchert, Till-Holger]]. "Hans Memling and Rogier van der Weyden". In: J. Chapuis (ed), ''Invention: Northern Renaissance Studies in honor of Molly Faries''. Turnhout: Brepols, 2008. {{ISBN|978-2-503-52768-0}} *[[Lorne Campbell (Art historian)|Campbell, Lorne]]. ''Van der Weyden''. New York: Harper and Row, 1980. {{ISBN|0-06-430650-X}}
